Starting efforts to promote transparency and accountability can be a complex process, and it requires the engagement of multiple stakeholders, including citizens, governments, and organizations. Here are some steps that can be taken to encourage people to use transparency-promoting tools and to force governments and organizations to be more transparent:

1. Awareness raising: Raise awareness among citizens and stakeholders about the importance of transparency and accountability, and the role that data and technology can play in promoting these values. This can be done through public campaigns, community outreach, and other efforts to educate and engage people.
2. Building partnerships: Build partnerships with governments, organizations, and other stakeholders to promote transparency and accountability. This can include working with technology providers, civil society organizations, and other groups to create and implement transparency-promoting tools.
3. Encouraging use: Encourage people to use transparency-promoting tools by making them accessible, user-friendly, and relevant to their needs. This can include providing training and support to help people use the tools effectively, and ensuring that data and information is easily accessible and understandable.
4. Enforcing transparency regulations: Governments and organizations can be encouraged to be more transparent by enforcing existing regulations and implementing new transparency measures. This can include passing laws that require organizations to report on their activities, establishing oversight mechanisms to monitor compliance, and imposing consequences for non-compliance.
5. Supporting civil society: Support the efforts of civil society organizations and other stakeholders to promote transparency and accountability. This can include providing funding and other resources to support their work, and amplifying their voices in public debates and discussions.

These are just a few examples of the steps that can be taken to encourage people to use transparency-promoting tools and to force governments and organizations to be more transparent. By taking a comprehensive approach and engaging multiple stakeholders, it is possible to create a culture of transparency and accountability that can help to address poverty and other complex challenges.
